tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This question requires understanding of static equilibrium and beam loading. It involves calculating reactions based on a distributed load, which requires multiple steps and integration of concepts. The image is essential for understanding the load distribution.

answer_validation.reasoning: The beam is simply supported at A (pin) and B (roller). The transverse load varies linearly from a maximum value q_0 at A to zero at B, forming a right triangular distributed load with base length L and height q_0. The resultant of a triangular load equals the area of the triangle and acts at its centroid, which is located at one-third of the base length from the larger-intensity end. Therefore, the equivalent point load is \(Q = \tfrac{1}{2} q_0 L\) acting at a distance \(x = L/3\) from A (towards B). Taking moments about A: \(R_B L = Q x = (\tfrac{1}{2} q_0 L)(L/3) = q_0 L^2 / 6\), so \(R_B = q_0 L / 6\). From vertical force equilibrium: \(R_A + R_B = Q = q_0 L / 2\), giving \(R_A = q_0 L / 2 - q_0 L / 6 = q_0 L / 3\). Hence \(R_A = q_0 L / 3\) and \(R_B = q_0 L / 6\), so \(R_A > R_B\). Thus option A, stating that the vertical reaction at A is larger than that at B, is correct.

step_by_step: Identify the loading: a linearly varying (triangular) distributed load with intensity q_0 at A and zero at B over span L.
Replace the triangular distributed load by an equivalent single resultant force Q equal to the area of the triangle: Q = (1/2) q_0 L.
Locate the line of action of Q. For a right triangle, the centroid lies at one-third of the base from the larger-intensity side, so Q acts at x = L/3 from support A.
Apply moment equilibrium about A: R_B * L = Q * x = (1/2 q_0 L) * (L/3) to find R_B = q_0 L / 6.
Apply vertical force equilibrium: R_A + R_B = Q = q_0 L / 2, giving R_A = q_0 L / 3.
Compare magnitudes: R_A = q_0 L / 3 is greater than R_B = q_0 L / 6, so the reaction at A is larger than at B.

topic.name: Shear force, bending moment and support reactions in beams
topic.syllabus_ref: Section 3 Structures -> Bending of beams, shear force and bending moment

essential: Basic statics: conditions for equilibrium of a rigid body
Concept of distributed load and its equivalent resultant force
Centroid location for standard area shapes such as triangles
Support types and reaction components for pin and roller supports
helpful: Shear force and bending moment diagrams for beams
Understanding of how load distribution influences reaction magnitudes

Main Concept: requires: Basic statics equilibrium (sum of forces and moments equals zero)
requires: Ability to replace a distributed load by an equivalent point load at its centroid
enables: Analysis of beams with more complex non-uniform loadings
enables: Construction of shear force and bending moment diagrams for aircraft structural members

difficulty_factors: Requires recalling centroid location of a triangular load distribution
Students may be tempted to assume equal reactions due to symmetric supports, ignoring asymmetric loading

textbook_references.author: T.H.G. Megson
textbook_references.chapter_title: Shear Force and Bending Moment in Beams
textbook_references.section: Resultant of distributed loads and support reactions

textbook_references.author: Beer, Johnston et al.
textbook_references.section: Shear and bending moment diagrams; distributed loads
textbook_references.text_snippet: For a simply supported beam with a uniformly distributed load, the reactions are obtained by replacing the load with its resultant acting at the centroid of the load distribution.

video_references.book_reference: Megson - Aircraft Structures for Engineering Students
video_references.topic_covered: Shear force and bending moment for beams under uniformly distributed loads and calculation of reactions
Support reactions and SFD/BMD for simply supported beams with distributed loads

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Replace distributed load by resultant -> Locate centroid -> Apply moment equilibrium -> Apply force equilibrium -> Compare reactions
key_insights: A non-uniform (triangular) load has its resultant closer to the higher-intensity end, increasing the reaction at that support.
Support symmetry does not imply reaction symmetry; the load distribution controls reaction magnitudes.

formulas_principles.name: Resultant of triangular distributed load
formulas_principles.conditions: Triangular load varying linearly from q_0 to 0 over span L
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to replace the distributed load with an equivalent point load.

formulas_principles.name: Centroid location of right triangle from larger side
formulas_principles.conditions: Right triangular load with base L and larger intensity at the reference end
formulas_principles.relevance: Gives the distance of the resultant load from support A.

formulas_principles.name: Vertical force equilibrium
formulas_principles.conditions: Static equilibrium of the beam in vertical direction
formulas_principles.relevance: Relates support reactions to the resultant load.

formulas_principles.name: Moment equilibrium about A
formulas_principles.conditions: Sum of moments about support A equals zero
formulas_principles.relevance: Allows solving for reaction at B.

industry_examples: Wing or tailplane spars experiencing linearly varying aerodynamic pressure, higher near the root and lower near the tip.
Bridge decks with traffic or wind loads that vary along the span, approximated as triangular distributions.
specific_systems: Aircraft wing root bending analysis where lift distribution is approximated as triangular for preliminary sizing.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Correct estimation of support reactions is essential for sizing supports, joints, and fasteners in aircraft structures and civil structures; underestimating a reaction can lead to unsafe designs or failure.

common_mistakes.mistake: Assuming that because the beam is simply supported at both ends, the vertical reactions at A and B must be equal.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They overgeneralize from the symmetric case of uniform loading and ignore the asymmetric load distribution.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always check whether the loading is symmetric. Only if both geometry and loading are symmetric about the mid-span will the reactions be equal.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to choosing option C and incorrect reaction values in calculations.

common_mistakes.mistake: Placing the resultant of the triangular load at mid-span (L/2) instead of at L/3 from the higher-intensity end.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They confuse the centroid of a triangle with that of a rectangle or think 'middle of the span' by habit.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Memorize and visualize that the centroid of a right triangle lies one-third from each base side; draw a small triangle and mark its centroid while revising.
common_mistakes.consequence: Gives wrong reaction magnitudes and possibly wrong sign trends in SFD/BMD.

common_mistakes.mistake: Taking moments about the wrong point or using incorrect lever arms for the resultant load.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: In a hurry, they forget to measure distances from the chosen moment center.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: When writing moment equations, explicitly sketch the distances from the reference point and label them before substituting.
common_mistakes.consequence: Incorrect numerical values of reactions even if the conceptual understanding is correct.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Centroid of a triangular load is at L/3 from the side with larger intensity
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use whenever you see a triangular distributed load on a beam.

flashcards.front: Where does the resultant of a triangular distributed load act relative to the larger-intensity end?
flashcards.back: At a distance of L/3 from the larger-intensity end along the beam span, where L is the base length of the triangular load.

flashcards.front: A beam carries a triangular load varying from 0 to q_0 over length L. What is the magnitude of the equivalent point load?
flashcards.back: The equivalent point load is the area of the triangle: Q = (1/2) q_0 L.

flashcards.front: Simply supported beam, triangular load q_0 at A to 0 at B over L. Which support has the larger vertical reaction?
flashcards.back: Support A has the larger reaction because the resultant of the triangular load is closer to A (at L/3 from A), giving R_A = q_0 L / 3 and R_B = q_0 L / 6.

flashcards.front: True or False: For any simply supported beam, reactions at the two supports are equal.
flashcards.back: False. Reactions are equal only when the loading and geometry are symmetric about the mid-span. Asymmetric loads (e.g., triangular) give unequal reactions.

real_world_context.application: Lift distribution on an aircraft wing approximated as triangular (higher at root, lower at tip).
real_world_context.industry_example: In preliminary wing design, engineers may assume a triangular lift distribution to estimate root bending moments and support reactions at the wing-fuselage joint.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Underestimating the root reaction can lead to undersized spars or attachment fittings, risking structural failure under flight loads.

real_world_context.application: Cantilever balconies or overhangs with linearly varying loads due to snow drift or parapet walls.
real_world_context.industry_example: Structural engineers compute reactions at building columns supporting such beams using equivalent triangular loads.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Accurate reactions ensure columns and foundations are designed with adequate safety margins.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Recognize this as a quick statics question: convert the triangular load to a single resultant at L/3 from the heavy end and compare reactions; no detailed SFD/BMD is needed.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If you recall that the load is heavier near A, the support closer to the heavier side (A) must carry more reaction, so choose the option stating R_A > R_B.
exam_strategy.time_management: Aim to finish within 1â€“2 minutes; if you find yourself writing long equations, step back and use the centroid shortcut.

search_keywords: centroid of triangular load L/3 rule
shear force bending moment triangular loading

alternative_methods.name: Integration of load intensity function
alternative_methods.description: Model the load as q(x) = q_0 (1 - x/L) from A to B. Integrate q(x) over 0 to L to find the total load Q, and integrate x q(x) to find the moment about A, then use equilibrium to solve for reactions.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Generalizable to any load function and reinforces calculus-based understanding. Cons: More algebraic work than using standard centroid formulas for simple shapes.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful when the load variation is not a simple standard shape or when practicing calculus-based beam analysis.

connections_to_other_subjects.Engineering Mechanics: Uses the same principles of equivalent force systems and centroids of area distributions.
connections_to_other_subjects.Solid Mechanics: Beam reaction calculations are the starting point for determining internal shear forces, bending moments, and stresses.
connections_to_other_subjects.Aerospace Structures: Wing and fuselage load distributions are often non-uniform; understanding reactions is key to sizing structural members.

deeper_dive_topics: Derivation of shear force and bending moment diagrams for beams under triangular and trapezoidal loads
Influence lines for reactions in beams with moving triangular loads
Application of distributed aerodynamic loads on aircraft wings and control surfaces

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Bending of beams, shear force and bending moment, support reactions
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Well-aligned conceptual question testing understanding of non-uniform loads and support reactions without heavy computation.

rag_quality.notes: RAG chunks mainly discussed simply supported beams under uniformly distributed loads, including reactions, SFD, BMD, and deflections. While the current question involves a triangular (linearly varying) load rather than uniform, the underlying principles of replacing distributed loads with resultants and using equilibrium are the same. Specific triangular-load centroid details were supplied from internal knowledge.

future_questions_potential: Ask for the exact numerical values of reactions R_A and R_B for given q_0 and L under triangular loading.
Extend to drawing the shear force and bending moment diagrams for the same triangularly loaded simply supported beam.
Modify the problem to a cantilever beam with triangular load and ask for fixed-end reactions and maximum bending moment.
Combine multiple load types (point load plus triangular load) and ask for reactions or location of zero shear.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: A simply supported horizontal beam is subjected to a distributed transverse load varying linearly from $q_0$ at A to zero at B, as shown in the figure. Which one of the following options is correct?
